frontmatter.title: Chapter 3: Introduction to Git and GitHub
frontmatter.subject: Modeling the Universe

children.value: Why Version Control Will Save Your Research

children.label: Why Version Control Will Save Your Research

children.value: It‚Äôs 2 AM, three days before your thesis defense. You accidentally delete 400 lines of working code while trying to ‚Äúclean up.‚Äù Or worse‚Äîyour laptop dies, taking six months of work with it.
This happens to someone every semester.
Git prevents these disasters. It‚Äôs your safety net, collaboration tool, and scientific record all in one. By the end of this guide, you‚Äôll never lose work again.
After this guide, you‚Äôll be able to:
‚úì Never lose code again (even if your laptop explodes)
‚úì Collaborate without fear of overwriting others‚Äô work
‚úì Track exactly what changed and when

stellar_evolution.py
stellar_evolution_v2.py
stellar_evolution_v2_FIXED.py
stellar_evolution_v2_FIXED_actually_works.py
stellar_evolution_OLD_DO_NOT_DELETE.py
stellar_evolution_FINAL.py
stellar_evolution_FINAL_REAL.py
stellar_evolution_FINAL_REAL_USE_THIS_ONE.py
With Git, you have ONE file with complete history. Every change is tracked, documented, and reversible.

graph LR A[Working Directory
Your files] -->|git add| B[Staging Area
Ready to save] B -->|git commit| C[Repository
Permanent history] C -->|git push| D[GitHub
Cloud backup] D -->|git pull| A
If not installed, it will prompt you to install Xcode Command Line Tools.

# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install git

# Fedora
sudo dnf install git
‚ÄúGit from the command line and also from 3rd-party software‚Äù
‚ÄúUse Visual Studio Code as Git‚Äôs default editor‚Äù
for all Git commands (not Command Prompt).

# Tell Git who you are (for commit messages)
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@sdsu.edu"

# Set default branch name to 'main' (GitHub's default)
git config --global init.defaultBranch main

# Set default editor (optional but helpful)
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"  # For VS Code

# Verify configuration
git config --list
The pack includes professional tools worth thousands of dollars:
: AI pair programmer (disabled for this course initially)
Verification typically takes 1-72 hours. You‚Äôll get an email when approved.
GitHub no longer accepts passwords for Git operations. You need either:
We‚Äôll use Personal Access Tokens (classic) for simplicity. GitHub also offers ‚Äúfine-grained‚Äù tokens with more security, but classic tokens are simpler for course work.
Go to GitHub ‚Üí Click your profile picture ‚Üí Settings
Set expiration to after the semester ends

# Configure Git to remember credentials (so you don't paste token every time)
git config --global credential.helper cache  # Linux/Mac: remembers for 15 min
git config --global credential.helper manager  # Windows: saves permanently

# First time you push, Git asks for:
# Username: your-github-username
# Password: paste-your-token-here (NOT your GitHub password!)

When Git asks for ‚Äúpassword‚Äù, paste your TOKEN, not your actual GitHub password!
The token acts as your password for Git operations.
Master these five commands and you can use Git for this entire course:
GitHub Classroom automates assignment distribution and collection:
Professor creates assignment with starter code
You get a personalized repository (forked from template)
Your last push before deadline = your submission
No uploading files, no Canvas submissions, no ‚Äúdid you get my email?‚Äù
: As of 2024, GitHub Classroom creates student repos as forks, allowing professors to update starter code even after you‚Äôve accepted the assignment.
Select your name from the roster
You‚Äôll see ‚ÄúYour assignment has been created‚Äù
Click the link to your repository

# 1. Clone your assignment repository
git clone https://github.com/sdsu-astr596/project1-yourusername.git
cd project1-yourusername

# 2. Work on your code
# Edit files, test, debug...

# 3. Check what's changed
git status

# 4. Stage your changes
git add .

# 5. Commit with descriptive message
git commit -m "Implement stellar mass calculation"

# 6. Push to GitHub (this is your submission!)
git push
Your submission is whatever is pushed to GitHub by the deadline!
You can push unlimited times before deadline
to verify your code is there
Check that your latest changes are visible
Look for the green checkmark on your commit
Check the timestamp (must be before deadline!)
üí° Pro Tip: Push Early and Often
Don‚Äôt wait until 11:59 PM to push!
Push every time you make progress:
This way you always have a submission, even if something goes wrong at the last minute.

# Create project folder
mkdir my_analysis
cd my_analysis

# Initialize Git repository
git init

# Create a Python file
echo "print('Hello ASTR 596!')" > hello.py

# Create a .gitignore file
cat > .gitignore << EOF
# Python
__pycache__/
*.py[cod]
*$py.class
*.so
.Python
env/
venv/
.ipynb_checkpoints/
.pytest_cache/

# Data files (usually too large)
*.fits
*.hdf5
*.npy
*.npz
data/

# OS files
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db
.Trash-*

# IDE
.vscode/
.idea/
*.swp
*.swo

# Personal
scratch/
notes_to_self.txt
EOF

# Check status
git status

# Add everything
git add .

# First commit
git commit -m "Initial commit with hello.py and .gitignore"

# Start of work session
git pull                     # Get latest changes (if working with others)

# ... do your work ...

git status                    # What changed?
git diff                      # See specific changes
git add .                     # Stage everything
git commit -m "Clear message" # Save snapshot
git push                      # Backup to cloud
‚ÄúFix energy conservation bug in leapfrog integrator‚Äù
‚ÄúAdd mass-luminosity relationship for main sequence stars‚Äù
‚ÄúOptimize N-body force calculation with spatial hashing‚Äù
Future you will thank current you for clear messages!

git commit
# Opens editor for multi-line message:

# Fix incorrect gravitational constant in N-body simulation
#
# The constant was off by a factor of 4œÄ due to unit conversion
# error. This affected all orbital period calculations.
# 
# Fixes #12

git push
# Error: failed to push some refs...

# Solution:
git pull
# If there are conflicts, resolve them (see below)
git push
‚ÄúI Made a Mistake in My Last Commit‚Äù

children.label: ‚ÄúI Made a Mistake in My Last Commit‚Äù

children.value:
# Fix the file
# Then amend the commit
git add .
git commit --amend -m "New message"
git push --force  # Only if you already pushed!

# Discard changes to specific file (not staged)
git checkout -- file.py

# Undo last commit but keep changes
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# Nuclear option: discard ALL local changes
git reset --hard HEAD

<<<<<<< HEAD
your changes
=======
their changes
>>>>>>> branch-name

# Keep the version you want (or combine them)
combined final version

git add .
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict"
git push
Add a Python file with a simple function
Make some changes to a file
Make new changes and commit them
You‚Äôre ready for this course when you can:
Clone a repository from GitHub Classroom
Make changes and commit them with clear messages
Check status and diff before committing
You‚Äôre ready to use Git for all assignments!
You‚Äôre using SSH but haven‚Äôt set up keys
Or set up SSH keys (see GitHub docs)
Create new token following steps above
Make sure to paste TOKEN, not password
Check you‚Äôre in the right directory:
If already pushed, contact instructor immediately

git stash          # Save changes temporarily
git stash pop      # Restore changes

git show abc123    # Show specific commit
git diff HEAD~2    # Compare with 2 commits ago

git bisect start
git bisect bad      # Current version is broken
git bisect good v1.0  # v1.0 was working
# Git helps you find when bug was introduced

git config --global alias.st status
git config --global alias.cm commit
git config --global alias.br branch
# Now use: git st, git cm, etc.

## Resources

- **Official Git Book** (free): https://git-scm.com/book
- **GitHub's Tutorial**: https://try.github.io
- **Visual Git Guide**: https://marklodato.github.io/visual-git-guide/
- **Oh Shit, Git!?!**: https://ohshitgit.com (recovery from mistakes)
- **GitHub Classroom Guide**: https://classroom.github.com/help

## Next Steps

1. ‚úÖ Git is configured
2. ‚úÖ GitHub account ready
3. ‚úÖ Can clone, commit, and push
4. ‚Üí Continue to [Command Line Interface Guide](03-cli-intro-guide)
5. ‚Üí Accept your first assignment on GitHub Classroom!

---

**Remember:** Git seems complex but you only need ~5 commands for this course. Focus on the essential workflow: `status`, `add`, `commit`, `push`, `pull`. Everything else is optional!
